list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Two identical masses of magnitude $m$ are attached to the opposite ends of a solid beam of negligible mass and total length $l$.
The beam is suspended from its centre and rotates about a vertical axis at constant angular speed $\omega$ as shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7097837f-f2c7-411c-aa60-2da2311be6e3/images/ae44f322-e8d7-4dae-872f-8891d75d9147/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.38.50%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly expresses the magnitude of the angular momentum of the system around its axis of rotation?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{4}ml^2\omega$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{2}ml^2\omega$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $ml^2\omega$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $2ml^2\omega$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The moment of inertia of the system can be expressed as:


- $I=m\Bigl(\dfrac{l}{2}\Bigr)^2+m\Bigl(\dfrac{l}{2}\Bigr)^2=\dfrac{1}{2} ml^2$

The magnitude of the angular momentum is then:


- $L=I\omega=\dfrac{1}{2}ml^2\omega$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
A point mass $m$ is attached to the end of a uniform beam with negligible mass and length $l$. The beam is placed horizontally with its other end hinged from a fixed point .
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/58de076c-06f7-4703-a69d-e4979e09a47c/images/9962388e-34b4-45ae-838c-e1d191f5a8dc/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.40.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The system is released from rest and as it falls it rotates around point A.
Which of the following correctly describes the magnitude of the initial angular acceleration of the system?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{l}{g}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2l}{g}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{g}{l}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2g}{l}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
As it is released, the beam rotates around point A due to the torque exerted by the force of gravity on the mass, a distance $l$ from A .


- $\tau=mgl$

The moment of inertia around point A corresponds to the one of a point mass at a distance $l$:


- $I=m l^2$

These two expressions can be substituted into $\tau=I\alpha$ leading to:


- $mgl=ml^2\alpha$

Then:


- $\alpha=\dfrac{g}{l}$

$\underline{\text{Alternatively}}$:
Because the beam is massless, at this instant the point mass $m$ can be considered to be in freefall, with acceleration $g$.
angular acceleration $\alpha = \dfrac{a}{r} = \dfrac{g}{l}$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A solid sphere with radius $r$ and mass $m$ is rolling along a horizontal surface without slipping with an angular speed $\omega$ as shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/844bdedd-7b5b-4192-9bbf-7d01de90f21a/images/f5a92c5f-61a6-4b9a-a483-5f4c44ab6e69/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.20.53%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly describes the magnitude of the linear momentum of the sphere?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $m\omega r$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $m{\omega}^2r$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $m\omega r^2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{m\omega}{r}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Given that the sphere rolls without slipping, the center of mass is moving with a speed equal to the speed of a point on the circumference of a circle of radius $r$ rotating at an angular speed $\omega$.


- $v_{center}=\omega r$

The magnitude of the linear momentum ($p=mv$) is then:


- $p=m\omega r$

- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $600$ N
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $800$ N
list.markScheme:

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The beam is in equilibrium which means that the total torque (from any point) must be zero.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
A wheel rotates from rest with uniform angular acceleration. At time $16$ s, its angular velocity is 5 revolutions per second.
What is the angular displacement of the wheel during this time, in radians?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  20\pi\, $
- B. $\hspace{1em}  40\pi\,$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  80\pi\,$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  160\pi\,$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The wheel starts from rest


- $ω_i=0$

Each revolution corresponds to angular displacement of $2\pi$ rad
Therefore


- $ω_f=(5)(2)π=10\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$

The angular displacement after $16$ s is


- $\Delta \theta=\dfrac{ω_f+ω_i}{2} t$
- $\Delta \theta=  \bigg(\dfrac{10π+0}{2}\bigg) (16)=80\pi$ rad

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
An object sits on a rotating horizontal disc of radius $r$. The disc rotates from rest with uniform angular acceleration $\alpha$. After time $t$ the object slides off of the disc.
What is the linear speed of the object at this time?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  \alpha t$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  r\alpha t$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{2}\alpha t^2$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{2}r\alpha t^2$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The angular speed after time $t$ is


- $\omega_f=\omega_i+\alpha t$
- $\omega_f =\alpha t$

The linear speed is given by


- $v=\omega r$
- $v=\alpha tr = r\alpha t$

list.title: Question 7

The graph below shows the angular momentum $L$ of a rotating solid object against time.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/acac60b0-27ab-45d7-8acb-32d84d999a86/images/6ca1d35a-89c8-4311-be89-4a82c85c7486/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%2010.49.35%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Which of the following correctly describes the gradient of the graph?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ Angular acceleration
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ Angular speed
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ Moment of inertia
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ Net torque
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The gradient of the graph corresponds to:


- gradient $=\dfrac{\Delta L}{\text{time}}$

The change in angular momentum $\Delta L$ can be expressed as $I \Delta \omega$.


- gradient $=\dfrac{I\Delta \omega}{\text{time}}$

The ratio $\dfrac{\Delta \omega}{\text{time}}$ corresponds to the (average) angular acceleration which in this case, given that the graph is linear, is constant.


- gradient $=I\alpha$

This corresponds to the net torque acting on the object.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
A tightrope walker holds a long pole during his stunt.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4c7ddc13-3145-47cd-82f8-f6060f55beff/images/871c6978-0c29-41b7-a982-8998112032d9/PH0705.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by  Mote Oo Education from Pixabay]}}$
Three statements are given about the effect of the pole on the walker's ability to maintain their balance.


- I.	The pole increases the moment of inertia of the walker.
- II.	Use of the pole means that an unbalanced torque will produce a smaller angular acceleration to the walker and pole.
- III.	Holding the pole higher will make the walker more stable.

Which of these statements is/are correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The moment of inertia is given by


- $I=\Sigma mr^2$

When the walker holds a long pole, the moment of inertia of the pole is added to that of the walker.  Because the ends of the pole are quite far from the rope, the pole's moment of inertia is high. Therefore I is correct.
The relation between torque and angular acceleration is given by
$\tau =I\alpha$
Since the moment of inertia is high, then when there is a torque the angular acceleration will be small. Therefore II is correct
Raising and lowering the pole will effectively raise and lower the centre of mass of the walker/pole system. If the centre of mass is further from the rope, then it will increase the torque that would result if the centre of mass would stray from directly above the rope. This is because $\tau=Fr sin\theta$, and so an increase in $r$ will increase the torque. Therefore III is incorrect.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
A disk rotates with constant angular acceleration. In a time $t$ angular speed increases from $\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$ to 5$\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$ across $9$ full rotations. Which of the following gives the angular acceleration of the disk $\alpha$ and the time $t$?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\alpha$/$\textrm{rad s}^{-2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $t\textrm{/s}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{2\pi}{3}$3$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{2\pi}{3}$6$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{3\pi}{2}$3$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{3\pi}{2}$6
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Here we have:


- $\omega_i=\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$
- $\omega_f=5\pi$ rad s$^{-1}$
- $\Delta\theta=(2\pi)(9)=18\pi$

To find time $t$ we can use the equation:


- $\Delta\theta=\dfrac{\omega_i+\omega_f}{2}t$

Substituting our values and rearranging for $t$ we have:


- $18\pi=\bigg(\dfrac{\pi+5\pi}{2}\bigg)t$
- $36\pi=6\pi t$
- $t=\dfrac{36}{6}=6$ s

To find angular acceleration $\alpha$ we can use the equation:


- $(\omega_f)^2=(\omega_i)^2+2\alpha\Delta\theta$

Substituting our values and rearranging for $t$ we have:


- $(5\pi)^2=\pi^2-2\alpha(18\pi)$
- $25\pi^2=\pi^2-36\pi\alpha$
- $24\pi=36\alpha$
- $\alpha=\dfrac{24\pi}{36}=\dfrac{2\pi}{3}$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
A uniform beam of total length $L$ and mass $m$ is hinged on one end and acted upon by a horizontal force of magnitude $F$ on its other end.
The beam is held stationary at rest at an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal as shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/648289e9-f8b8-498b-a242-e4013c1aede6/images/2a6cb9b3-26cf-446b-82e6-8eaa0049c35a/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.37.01%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly expresses the value of $F$?



- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $2mg\tan{\theta}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2mg}{\tan{\theta}}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{mg}{2\tan{\theta}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{mg\tan{\theta}}{2}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The beam is in rotational equilibrium which means that the total torque (from any point) must be zero.
Taking the axis of the hinge as the centre of torques there are two forces exerting torque on the beam: weight and the horizontal force of magnitude $F$.
The magnitude of the torque exerted by the weight is given by:


- ${\tau}_{weight}=\dfrac{L}{2}mg\cos{\theta}$

The magnitude of the torque exerted by the horizontal force is given by:


- ${\tau}_F=L(\sin{\theta}) F$

By equating these equations, we get:


- $\dfrac{L}{2}mg\cos{\theta} = L(\sin{\theta}) F$

Which can be solved for $F$ leading to:


- $F=\dfrac{mg\cos{\theta}}{2\sin{\theta}}=\dfrac{mg}{2\tan{\theta}}$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
An object which is initially rotating with a frequency of 2 s$^{-1}$. It is acted upon a constant torque which produces an angular deceleration of magnitude 6 rad s$^{-2}$.
Which of the following best describes the number of complete rotations of the object until it comes to rest?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ 2
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ 3
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ 4
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ 6
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The angular speed can be expressed in terms of the frequency of rotation $f$ as:


- $\omega=2\pi f$

The object is initially rotating with an angular speed equal to:


- $\omega = 2\pi (2\textrm{ s}^{-1} )$
- $\omega = 4\pi \, \text{rad}\textrm{ s}^{-1}$

Given that the torque is described constant (constant angular acceleration) the following equation from the booklet can be used:


- ${\omega}_f^2={\omega}_i^2+2\alpha \theta$

Substituting the given values and the fact that as the object comes to a rest $ω_f$ is zero, the equation can be written as:


- $0=(4\pi \, \text{rad s}^{-1})^2+2(-6\,\text{rad s}^{-2} )\theta $

Solving for $\theta$ leads to:


- $\theta=\dfrac{(4\pi \, \text{rad s}^{-1})^2}{12\, \text{rad s}^{-2}}=\dfrac{4}{3}{\pi}^2 \, \text{rad}$

This value represents the angle through which the object rotates until coming to a rest. It can then be divided by $2\pi$ leading to the number of complete rotations.


- #rotations $=\dfrac{\theta}{2\pi}=\dfrac{2}{3}\pi$
- #rotations $\approx 2.09$

    - $\omega\ =\ \dfrac{2}{0.22} \sqrt{\dfrac{(9.8)\ (1.5)}{3}}\ =\ 20.1\textrm{ rad s}^{-1}$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
A uniform rod of mass $M$ and length $L$ rotates around a vertical axis through its center. Two equal forces act on the rod as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc8552b-f2af-406e-9782-98ecc856ffa9/images/643b69ac-8b0a-4838-b20d-66e33be9978b/Screenshot%202023-08-07%20at%202.12.35%20PM.png)


The moment of inertia of the rod when rotating about its centre is  $\dfrac{1}{12} ML^2$.
Which of the following gives the angular acceleration of the rod?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  0$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{6F}{ML}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{12F}{ML}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{24F}{ML}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The net torque of the two forces is


- $\tau =2Fr$

Since


- $r=\dfrac{L}{2}$

Then


- $\tau =2F\dfrac{L}{2}=FL$

- B. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{L^2 (M+4m)}{9}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  L^2 (M+m)$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  L^2 (M+4m)$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since


- $\dfrac{\textrm{Distance\ between\ M\ and\ the\ axis}}{\textrm{Distance\ between\ m\ and\ the\ axis} }=
  \dfrac{1}{2}$

Then


- Distance between $M$ and the axis = $\dfrac{L}{3}$

and


- Distance between $m$ and the axis = $\dfrac{2L}{3}$

The moment of inertia is given by


- $I=\Sigma mr^2$
- $I=M\dfrac{L^2}{9} + m\dfrac{4L^2}{9}$
- $\dfrac{L^2(M+4m)}{9}$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Three identical masses, $A$, $B$, and $C$ are connected in a straight line by two identical rods of negligible mass and length $l$. A force $F$ is applied at $C$, perpendicular to the line $ABC$. There is no gravitational field, and the masses are considered point masses.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/751acc25-812a-40f8-b82f-02034a2a6ace/images/2e1920d5-56f2-4018-a3fa-1ece2da99379/PH1793q.JPEG)


When the system is pivoted at $A$ its angular acceleration is
$\alpha_A$. When the system is pivoted at $B$, its angular acceleration is $\alpha_B$.
What is the ratio $\dfrac{\alpha_A}{\alpha_B}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2}{5}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4}{5}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{5}{4}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{5}{2}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Angular acceleration $\alpha$ is given by:


- $\tau=I\alpha$

Where $\tau$ is torque and $I$ is moment of inertia.
Torque  is given by:


- $\tau=Fr$

Where $F$ is force and $r$ is the perpendicular distance between the force and the pivot.
Moment of inertia is given by:


- $I=\Sigma mr^2$

Where $m$ is mass and $r$ is the distance between the mass and the pivot.
Let the mass of $A$, $B$, and $C$ be $m$. When the system is pivoted at $A$ we have:


- $\tau=F(2l)=2Fl$
- $I=ml^2+m(2l)^2=5ml^2$
- $\alpha_A=\dfrac{\tau_A}{I_A}=\dfrac{2Fl}{5ml^2}=\dfrac{2F}{5ml}$

When the system is pivoted at $B$ we have:


- $\tau=Fl$
- $I=ml^2+ml^2=2ml^2$
- $\alpha_B=\dfrac{\tau_B}{I_B}=\dfrac{Fl}{ml^2}=\dfrac{F}{2ml}$
- $\dfrac{\alpha_A}{\alpha_B}=\dfrac{\dfrac{2F}{5ml}}{\dfrac{F}{2ml}}=\dfrac{\dfrac{2}{5}}{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{4}{5}$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
An inextensible string with negligible mass is wound around a fixed pulley of radius $r$ and moment of inertia $I$. The free end of the string is connected to a block of mass $M$ as shown in the figure.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8b31e2ba-87a7-474b-b2ec-2a8a84573086/images/cf66f4fa-875a-432a-84ee-234b98c86a2c/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.35.26%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The system is released from rest. Which of the following correctly describes the magnitude of the acceleration of the block?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{Mg}{M+\frac{I}{r^2}}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{Mg}{Mr^2+I}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{Mgr}{M+\frac{I}{r^2}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{Mgr}{Mr^2+I}$
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The block is acted upon two forces: weight (downwards) and tension (upwards). Newton's second law can be written as:


- $Mg-T=Ma$	(1)

Where $M$ is the mass of the block, $T$ the magnitude of the tension on the string and a the acceleration of the block.
The tension exerts a torque on the pulley with magnitude $Tr$, where $r$ is the radius of the pulley.
The angular acceleration $\alpha$ of the pulley is related to the tension on the string by the following equation:


- $Tr=I\alpha$	(2)

Given that the magnitude of the linear acceleration of the block is the same as the one on any point on the circumference of the pulley, it can be stated that:


- $a=\alpha r$	(3)

Solving equation (3) for $\alpha$ leads to:


- $\alpha=\dfrac{a}{r}$

This expression can be substituted in equation (2) leading to:


- $Tr=\dfrac{Ia}{r}$

Which can be solved for $T$ leading to


- $T=\dfrac{Ia}{r^2}$

This expression for $T$ can be substituted in equation (1).


- $Mg-\dfrac{Ia}{r^2} = Ma$
- $Mg=Ma+\dfrac{I}{r^2}a$

Solving for a leads to:


- $a=\dfrac{Mg}{M+\frac{I}{r^2}}$

From the student's perspective, the wheel rotates clockwise. Both the student and the chair are at rest.
The student inverted the direction of rotation of the wheel such that it is now turning anti-clockwise according to their perspective.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9a8dc27e-5ed3-4eb7-97c4-7129f270b9ef/images/cd5530d6-06c2-4269-bc06-31dc8b3bf218/PH0740b.png)

Which of the following is correct about both the student and the chair system?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $It remains at rest to keep the total momentum zero.
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $It rotates clockwise such that the total momentum is clockwise.
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $It rotates counterclockwise such that the total momentum is clockwise.
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $It rotates clockwise such that the total momentum is anticlockwise.
list.markScheme:

Due to conservation of angular momentum, the total initial momentum must be equal to the total final momentum.

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
A block with a mass $m_1$ is placed on a frictionless inclined plane. The plane is at an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal.
An inextensible string attached to his block is wound around a frictionless pulley with a radius $r$.
A second pulley with a radius $2r$ rotates together with the first one. A block with a mass $m_2$ hangs from this pulley, attached to a different string.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a0d6f744-58db-4b40-956d-5e71052e0f25/images/c563e171-8d54-45c9-904f-778778fe34ce/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.33.09%E2%80%AFPM.png)


If the system is in equilibrium, which of the following correctly expresses ratio $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{\sin{\theta}}{2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2}{\sin{\theta}}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $2\sin{\theta}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{1}{2\sin{\theta}}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The block which is placed on the inclined plane, according to Newton's first law, will be in (translational) equilibrium if:


- $T_1=m_1  g\sin{\theta}$

Where $T_1$ represents the tension on the string which runs over the pulley with a radius $r$.
The block with a mass $m_2$ will be in (translational) equilibrium if:


- $T_2=m_2 g$

Where $T_2$ is the magnitude of the tension on the string which runs over the pulley with a radius $2r$.
Finally, the pulley will be in (rotational) equilibrium if the torques that the strings are exerting, are balanced:


- $r T_1=2r T_2$

Substituting the expressions for $T_1$ and $T_2$ in this equation leads to:


- $r m_1 g\sin{\theta} = 2rm_2 g$

Which simplifies to


- $m_1 \sin{\theta} = 2 m_2$

and can then be re-arranged into:


- $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}=\dfrac{2}{\sin{\theta}}$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
Disc $A$ rotates around a vertical frictionless axle with angular speed $\omega_A$ and moment of inertia $I_A$. Disc $B$ with moment of inertia $I_B$ is dropped from rest on disc $A$. The ratio  $\dfrac{I_B}{I_A} =\dfrac{1}{4}$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a22bd7dc-181e-4b49-8bbb-3c5e95b3c65b/images/cf0c322f-91c7-4225-91be-c94aa69209c6/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.54.41%E2%80%AFAM.png)


The two discs have the same final angular speed $\omega$.
What is the ratio  $\dfrac{\textrm{(Final\ kinetic\ energy)}}{\textrm{(Initial\ kinetic\ energy)}}$  ?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{4}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{1}{2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{4}{5}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{5}{4}$
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From the given information,


- $I_B=\dfrac{1}{4} I_A$

Therefore


- $I_A+I_B=\dfrac{5}{4} I_A$

Due to conservation of angular momentum


- $L_i=L_f$



- $I_A \omega_A=(I_A+I_B)\omega$

since


- $\dfrac{I_B}{I_A} =\dfrac{1}{4}$

Then


- $4I_B \omega_A=5I_B \omega$



- $\omega=\dfrac{4}{5} \omega_A$

The initial kinetic energy is given by


- $E_{Ki}=\dfrac{1}{2} I_A \omega_A^2$

The final kinetic energy is given by


- $E_{Kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}(I_A+I_B)\omega^2$

The ratio between final and initial kinetic energy is given by
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
\hspace{1.3cm}\dfrac{Final\ kinetic\ energy}{initial\ kinetic\ energy}&=\dfrac{(\frac{1}{2}(I_A+I_B)\omega^2)}{(\frac{1}{4} I_A \omega_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{(\frac{5}{4}(I_A)\omega^2)}{(I_A \omega_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{(5ω^2)}{(4ω_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{(5(\frac{4}{5} ω_A)^2)}{(4ω_A^2 )}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\bigg(\dfrac{5}{4}\bigg)\bigg(\dfrac{16}{25}\bigg)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
&=\dfrac{4}{5}\\
\end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
A uniform rod of mass $M$ and length $L$ is pivoted at one of its ends. The rod is released from rest from the horizontal position.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b15f8f84-049c-456a-8829-8d8d12d78b52/images/8282415c-e1e7-4549-9c16-2d058ed04f1d/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.50.21%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


The moment of inertia of the rod when rotating about its end is  $\dfrac{1}{3}ML^2$.
What is the linear speed of the bottom end of the rod as it swings past the vertical position?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{\dfrac{3g}{L}}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{3gL}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{6gL}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{3g}{2L}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The center of mass of the rod at the horizontal position is higher than that at the vertical position by  $\dfrac{L}{2}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b15f8f84-049c-456a-8829-8d8d12d78b52/images/f7a199ca-a6be-4073-8541-12a68af8fbe6/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.52.25%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Then change in the gravitational potential energy between the horizontal position and the vertical position is


- $E_P=Mg \dfrac{L}{2}$

The rotational kinetic energy at the vertical position is given by


- $E_K=\dfrac{1}{2} I\omega^2$
- $E_K= \dfrac{1}{2} ( \dfrac{1}{3} ML^2 ) \omega^2=\dfrac{1}{6} ML^2 \omega^2$

According to the conservation of energy, the change in gravitational potential energy is equal to the kinetic energy at the vertical position.


- $E_P=E_K$



- $Mg \dfrac{L}{2}=\dfrac{1}{6} ML^2 ω^2$

Simplifying gives


- $\omega=\sqrt{\dfrac{3g}{L}}$

The linear speed is given by


- $v=r \omega$

For the other end of the rod


- $r=L$

Then


- $v=L\sqrt{\dfrac{3g}{L}}$
- $v=\sqrt{3gL}$
